title: Project 2: Linear Regression Modeling
text:
Overview
In this project, I built and evaluated a Linear Regression model using Python and scikit-learn.


Skills Demonstrated

Predictive Modeling
Model Evaluation
Data Visualization



Key Code Example


Import Libraries
import numpy as np import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression


Create sample data
np.random.seed(0) X = 2 * np.random.rand(100, 1) y = 4 + 3 * X + np.random.randn(100, 1)


Train model
model = LinearRegression() model.fit(X, y)


Predict values
y_pred = model.predict(X)


Model Coefficients
coef = model.coef_[0][0] intercept = model.intercept_[0] coef, intercept


Plot data and regression line
plt.scatter(X, y, color=‚Äúblue‚Äù, label=‚ÄúData Points‚Äù) plt.plot(X, y_pred, color=‚Äúred‚Äù, linewidth=2, label=‚ÄúRegression Line‚Äù) plt.title(‚ÄúLinear Regression Fit‚Äù) plt.xlabel(‚ÄúX‚Äù) plt.ylabel(‚Äúy‚Äù) plt.legend() plt.grid(True) plt.show()

title: Project 3: Web Scraping and Visualization
text:
Overview
In this project, I scraped data from the web using BeautifulSoup, processed it with Pandas, and created interactive visualizations with Plotly.


Skills Demonstrated

Web Scraping
Data Cleaning
Interactive Visualization



Key Code Example

import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd

# Simulated web scraping
html_content = """
<table>
<tr><th>Country</th><th>Population</th></tr>
<tr><td>USA</td><td>331 million</td></tr>
<tr><td>Canada</td><td>38 million</td></tr>
<tr><td>Mexico</td><td>128 million</td></tr>
</table>
"""

# Parse the HTML
soup = BeautifulSoup(html_content, "html.parser")
rows = soup.find_all("tr")

# Extract data
data = []
for row in rows[1:]:  # Skip header
    cols = row.find_all("td")
    country = cols[0].text
    population = cols[1].text
    data.append({"Country": country, "Population": population})

# Create DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df








Country
Population




0
USA
331 million


1
Canada
38 million


2
Mexico
128 million









üåç Visualization Example

import plotly.express as px

# Simple bar plot
fig = px.bar(df, x="Country", y="Population", title="Population by Country")
fig.show()
